description: Lu Xun was born in Shaoxing, where he grew up in a traditional Chinese family. His early experiences in this town influenced his later writings, particularly his critical view of Chinese society and culture.
Lu Xun studied in Nanjing at the Jiangnan Naval Academy, but his interest in literature led him to pursue a career in writing instead of joining the military.
Lu Xun studied medicine in Japan, but his passion for literature deepened during his time there, leading him to explore themes of social criticism and reform in his writing.
In Beijing, Lu Xun worked as a professor and writer, actively participating in the intellectual circles of the time and advocating for cultural and social change through his literary works.
Lu Xun moved to Shanghai and became a prominent figure in the literary scene, contributing to literary journals and magazines while continuing his critique of Chinese society and culture.
During his final year, Lu Xun returned to Beijing and continued to write and advocate for progressive ideas and social change.
Lu Xun passed away in Shanghai, leaving behind a legacy as one of the most influential Chinese writers of the 20th century.
